title: A New Minimax Theorem for Randomized Algorithms

sections.approximate degree:
The approximate degree of a (possibly partial)
Boolean function f:{0,1}nâ†’{0,1}:ğ‘“â†’superscript01ğ‘›01f\colon\{0,1\}^{n}\to\{0,1\}
is the minimum degree of an nğ‘›n-variate polynomial pğ‘p
which satisfies |pâ€‹(x)âˆ’fâ€‹(x)|â‰¤Ïµğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘“ğ‘¥italic-Ïµ|p(x)-f(x)|\leq\epsilon
for all xâˆˆDomâ¡(f)ğ‘¥Domğ‘“x\in\operatorname{Dom}(f), where Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is a parameter
representing the allowed error.
When fğ‘“f is a partial function,
there are actually two different notions of polynomial
degree: one where pğ‘p is required to be bounded

even when xâˆ‰Domâ¡(f)ğ‘¥Domğ‘“x\notin\operatorname{Dom}(f)), and one where pğ‘p
is not restricted outside the domain of fğ‘“f.
Our results will apply to both versions of polynomial
degree, but for conciseness, we restrict our attention
to the bounded version. With polynomials, it is often convenient to switch
from talking about functions f:{0,1}nâ†’{0,1}:ğ‘“â†’superscript01ğ‘›01f\colon\{0,1\}^{n}\to\{0,1\} to talking
about functions f:{+1,âˆ’1}nâ†’{+1,âˆ’1}:ğ‘“â†’superscript11ğ‘›11f\colon\{+1,-1\}^{n}\to\{+1,-1\}.
Note that by doing a simple variable substitution,
we can convert between {0,1}01\{0,1\} variables to {+1,âˆ’1}11\{+1,-1\}
variables without changing the degree of the polynomial.
That is, we can substitute 1âˆ’2â€‹xi12subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1-2x_{i} in place of the variable
xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} inside pğ‘p to make it take {0,1}01\{0,1\} inputs instead
of {+1,âˆ’1}11\{+1,-1\} inputs, and we can substitute
(1âˆ’xi)/21subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–2(1-x_{i})/2 to go the other way. We can similarly change
the output of pğ‘p from being in the range   [ref]1
to the range [âˆ’1,1]11[-1,1] and vice versa (the error
changes by a factor of 222 when switching between
these bases). Another well-known observation
is that to approximate a Boolean function fğ‘“f,
we only need multilinear polynomials,
and their degree only needs to be at most nğ‘›n. To get our hard distribution, we will use TheoremÂ 5.8.
We need to check the four conditions, but using

(bounded means that pâ€‹(x)âˆˆ[âˆ’1,1]ğ‘ğ‘¥11p(x)\in[-1,1] for all
xâˆˆ{+1,âˆ’1}nğ‘¥superscript11ğ‘›x\in\{+1,-1\}^{n}).
For a polynomial pâˆˆğ’œğ‘ğ’œp\in\mathcal{A}, we define biasfâ¡(p,x)subscriptbiasğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘¥\operatorname{bias}_{f}(p,x)
to be fâ€‹(x)â€‹pâ€‹(x)ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¥f(x)p(x). Then (1) holds,
as the set of polynomials of a given degree is convex
and biasfâ¡(â‹…,x)subscriptbiasğ‘“â‹…ğ‘¥\operatorname{bias}_{f}(\cdot,x) is linear over that set.
(2) holds because every Boolean function
can be computed exactly by a polynomial of degree nğ‘›n.
Next, (3) holds because polynomials
of degree less than 111 have degree 00, and since
weâ€™re dealing with bounded polynomials, these are a
convex combination of the two constant polynomials

let Pğ‘ƒP be a probability distribution over kğ‘˜k
polynomials q1,q2,â€¦,qksubscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜q_{1},q_{2},\dots,q_{k}, with degâ¡(qi)â‰¤2iâ€‹Tdegreesubscriptğ‘ğ‘–superscript2ğ‘–ğ‘‡\deg(q_{i})\leq 2^{i}T.
Let pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i} be the probability Pğ‘ƒP assigns to qisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–q_{i},
and suppose âˆ‘i=1k2iâ€‹piâ‰¤5superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘˜superscript2ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–5\sum_{i=1}^{k}2^{i}p_{i}\leq 5.

Our goal is to find a polynomial qğ‘q of degree
at most 2kâ€‹Tâ‹…polyâ¡(k)â‹…superscript2ğ‘˜ğ‘‡polyğ‘˜2^{k}T\cdot\operatorname{poly}(k) that computes fğ‘“f to
constant error. To do so, weâ€™ll need a polynomial
version of the amplitude estimation algorithm
we did in the quantum case. That is, weâ€™d like

Crucially, one of the arithmetic computations weâ€™d
like to do is comparison, for example, to see if

so we cannot use the polynomial qiâ€‹(x)subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘¥q_{i}(x) itself.
What weâ€™ll do instead is to create polynomials
that compute the bits of the binary expansion
of qiâ€‹(x)subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘¥q_{i}(x), to a certain precision. We will then
do arithmetic operations
using those bits, and weâ€™ll be able to implement
those operations using polynomials. To do so, weâ€™ll need some approximation theory.
The following theorem, known as Jacksonâ€™s theorem,
will be useful. It traces back to Jackson (1911)
[Jac11], but see also [MMR94] (page 750,

function, and let nâˆˆâ„•ğ‘›â„•n\in\mathbb{N}. Then there is
a real polynomial pğ‘p of degree nğ‘›n such that
for all xâˆˆ[âˆ’1,1]ğ‘¥11x\in[-1,1], we have In particular, if Î±ğ›¼\alpha
has Lipschitz constant Kğ¾K, then for each nâˆˆâ„•ğ‘›â„•n\in\mathbb{N}
there is a polynomial pnsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›p_{n} of degree
at most nğ‘›n which approximates

What does estimating qiâ€‹(x)subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘¥q_{i}(x) mean, for polynomials?
